title: Ancient Genomes Reveal Isolated Human Lineage in Southern Africa
summary: A recent study by a South African-Swedish team analyzed ancient DNA from skeletons in southern Africa, dating from 1,000 to over 10,000 years old. The research reveals a distinct human population that remained genetically isolated until approximately 1,200 years ago. Modern humans originated in Africa, but reconstructing internal migration patterns has been challenging due to poor DNA preservation in Africa's climate and the genetic mixing caused by events like the Bantu expansion. The study used statistical analysis to show that this southern African group formed a cluster separate from East and West African populations, indicating unique genetic diversity. Despite being isolated, the population was substantial in size, branching off from other lineages over 200,000 years ago. This finding provides insights into human evolution and highlights the complexity of Africa's demographic history, suggesting that climate and geography may have influenced this isolation.

background_read: This article discusses a scientific study on ancient human genomes from southern Africa. It explains that modern humans evolved in Africa, but internal history is unclear due to DNA degradation and population mixing. The study extracted DNA from skeletons up to 10,000 years old, revealing a lineage that stayed isolated until about 1,200 years ago. This challenges previous views and adds to our understanding of human diversity and migration in Africa.
Article_Structure: The article presents main points on a distinct southern African population isolated until recently, with purpose to clarify human evolutionary history in Africa. Evidence evaluation shows strong genetic data from ancient skeletons, though limited by sample age and preservation. Author credibility is supported by a joint South African-Swedish research team, likely experts in genetics and archaeology. Methodology involves DNA extraction and statistical analysis, providing reliable but incomplete insights due to Africa's challenging conditions for ancient DNA survival.
